title: How to Get Rid of Pimples with Baking Soda

steps.title: It may help dry it out a bit, but it’s not a particularly good solution.
steps.content: It may help dry it out a bit, but it’s not a particularly good solution. Baking soda will certainly dry out your skin, which may help if your pimple is caused by oily skin. However, there are better options out there when it comes to combatting oily skin and pimples. The main problem is that baking soda is a skin irritant, and while it’s not the world’s most dangerous thing to put on your skin, it’s definitely not the best option if you’re spot-treating pimples since the irritation cause make the problem worse. [2] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source However, some studies suggest that baking soda won’t even help with that. [3] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source All things considered, there just isn’t enough evidence that baking soda is going to be healthy or helpful for your skin.

steps.title: It’s probably not super dangerous, but it may irritate your skin.
steps.content: It’s probably not super dangerous, but it may irritate your skin. Baking soda is alkaline, and it has a pH of 8-9 which makes it moderately basic. [4] X Research source However, human skin has a natural pH of 4.5-5.3, meaning that it’s naturally acidic. [5] X Research source As a result, skin treatments that are slightly acidic or neutral is going to be much safer for your skin. [6] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Baking soda may help your pimple a bit if it’s caused by oily skin, but it’s just as likely to irritate your skin which may cause more pimples in the future. This is why scary-sounding ingredients like glycolic acid and alpha-hydroxyacid are commonly found in skincare products. The word “acid” conjures all kinds of fear-inducing ideas, but many acidic compounds are actually awesome for your skin. steps.title: No, this combination can seriously damage your skin.
steps.content: No, this combination can seriously damage your skin. Baking soda on its own is capable of irritating your skin, but lemon juice is seriously going to damage your skin barrier, which is the outermost layer of your skin. While many slightly acidic ingredients are safe for skin, lemon juice is not one of them; it has a pH of 2, which is wildly acidic. [8] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If you just think about it in this context, combining one skin irritant with another skin irritant isn’t going to create a winning combination that’s safe for your skin. [9] X Research source Your skin barrier is really important when it comes to protecting your skin from damage, disease, and dehydration, so you really don’t want to wear it down with something caustic, like citrus. [10] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Lemon juice may also cause discoloration in your skin; it’s a popular (albeit unsafe) skin whitening agent for this reason. [11] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: You don’t want to mix things together and put them on your skin.
steps.content: You don’t want to mix things together and put them on your skin. When you combine multiple ingredients at home, it’s very hard to know how the different chemicals will react with another, let alone how those reactions will impact your skin. [12] X Research source You’re always better off keeping it simple and using packaged products that have been tested, approved, and regulated by the government. [13] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Spot treat a single pimple with benzoyl peroxide.
steps.content: Spot treat a single pimple with benzoyl peroxide. Go to your local pharmacy and pick up an acne-fighting cream that contains benzoyl peroxide. After you clean your face, simply work a pea-sized dollop of the cream into the pimple and leave it alone. The benzoyl peroxide will reduce inflammation and kill any bacteria that’s clogging your pores, which is the most effective way to clear up any pimples. [14] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source There are also benzoyl peroxide patches and gels out there. If you want to use one of these, go for it! Benzoyl peroxide creams come in concentrations ranging from 2.5% to 10%. If you have sensitive skin, opt for the weaker concentrations. If you want to combat the pimple as aggressively as possible, pick up the stronger stuff. Don’t reapply the benzoyl peroxide multiple times a day. If you keep using it over and over again in the same spot, you may irritate your skin.

steps.title: Wash your face daily and don’t mess with your skin too much.
steps.content: Wash your face daily and don’t mess with your skin too much. You don’t need any fancy treatments or life hacks to get clear and healthy skin. Use an over-the-counter face wash once or twice a day, don’t go to bed with makeup on, and don’t scrub your facial skin too hard or too often. If you have a pimple, leave it alone. Don’t pop it or mess with it. Your skin is at its healthiest when you leave it alone, so just keep it clean and let it be! [15] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Eating a healthy diet and avoiding large amounts of sugars and carbohydrates may also minimize the odds that pimples occur. [16] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Never pop your pimples. This can lead to scarring, and you may make the area more inflamed and noticeable. [17] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: See a dermatologist to explore treatments for chronic acne.
steps.content: See a dermatologist to explore treatments for chronic acne. If you find yourself fighting pimples regularly, see a dermatologist. They’ll take a look at your skin and give you insight into what’s triggering your pimples. There could be an underlying issue you haven’t identified yet that may be causing your acne, like a hormonal issue or some irritant in your skincare products. Depending on their analysis, they’ll be able to recommend the ideal treatment for you. [18] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source There are certain medications your doctor may be able to prescribe to combat issues with hormonal acne. Light therapy may be something your doctor will be able to perform to treat your acne. A doctor may be able to perform a chemical peel to treat a large area and reduce inflammation.

steps.title: Most of the time, it’s going to take longer than 24 hours to treat a pimple.
steps.content: Most of the time, it’s going to take longer than 24 hours to treat a pimple. Treating your pimple with a benzoyl peroxide cream is the fastest way to get rid of it, but it’s not a miracle cure. In most instances, you’ll need to apply it multiple times over the course of multiple days and give your skin time to heal. If you want to hide your pimple, pick up a benzoyl peroxide patch or cover it up with a bandage.
